awd_abstract_narration:
Einstein's theory of general relativity describes all gravitational interactions in the universe, ranging from the force that pulls a falling apple to the Earth, to the expansion of the Universe itself.  The equations of general relativity - called Einstein's equations - are quite complicated and can be solved exactly, i.e. with pencil and paper, only under very special and unrealistic circumstances.  Modeling more realistic scenarios - for example in order to understand a gravitational wave signal, emitted by two merging black holes, and detected by the LIGO gravitational wave observatory - requires computer simulations.  This group's ongoing research efforts aim at developing methods and approaches for such computer simulations.  In recent years, the PI has developed new methods that are well suited for a new class of problems, and that may make current simulations significantly more efficient.  In the next few years he plans to adopt these methods to study so-called "critical phenomena" that occur at the onset of back-hole formation, to examine properties of rapidly rotating neutron stars, and to collaborate with colleagues to make the above-mentioned new methods available in public community codes.  Undergraduate students will participate in these activities, providing them with a "hands-on" research experience, and generating a research-enriched learning environment at Bowdoin College.

The scientific goals of this research effort in numerical relativity include the development and implementation of numerical algorithms for the solution of Einstein's equations of general relativity, as well as their application in the numerical modeling of relativistic objects, in particular neutron stars and black holes.  In the next funding period the PI plans to adopt methods for numerical relativity in spherical polar coordinates, previously developed with support from NSF grants, to study several problems in gravitational physics and relativistic astrophysics, in particular, to use this code to study critical collapse in the absence of spherical symmetry.  Extending earlier results the PI plans to study the effects of angular momentum and aspherical deformations on critical phenomena in the gravitational collapse of perfect fluids, scalar fields, and vacuum spacetimes, addressing several open questions.  The PI also plans to perform simulations of astrophysical objects; specifically, the stability of new types of differentially rotating neutron stars.  Finally, the PI will implement these methods for numerical relativity in curvilinear coordinates in efficient and scalable community codes, namely the Einstein Toolkit and Harm3D, so that these techniques can be applied in a number of astrophysical simulations that cannot be performed with current stand-alone codes.

por.por_cntn:
Einstein's theory of general relativity describes gravitation.  It describes all gravitational interactions, ranging from the gravitational forces we feel on the Earth, to the evolution and fate of the Universe itself.  It predicts objects and phenomena as exotic as black holes and gravitational waves - both of which were confirmed spectacularly when LIGO detected, for the first time, gravitational waves from two colliding black holes in 2015.  

 

Learning about such objects and phenomena, and the interactions between them, requires solving Einstein's equations, a complicated set of differential equations that form the core of general relativity.  For some simple cases these differential equations can be solved analytically, i.e. with pencil and paper, but for more general cases this is not possible.  In the field of "numerical relativity" we instead solve the equations numerically, writing computer programs that help us model black holes and other relativistic objects on the computer.   During my entire career, my research has been focussed on developing approaches and methods for numerical relativity, and the application of these methods to model astrophysical objects with strong gravitational fields, in particular black holes and neutron stars.  During the funding period of this grant I have made significant progress in several different areas.

 

Much of my recent work has utilized a new approach to numerical relativity that I have developed with the help of previous NSF funding, namely the use of so-called spherical coordinates.  To date, most numerical relativity codes use so-called Cartesian coordinates x, y, and z - think of space as a three-dimensional chess-board, in which the coordinates label each cube.  For many applications, however, it is more natural to use spherical coordinates, r, theta, and phi.  A familiar example is the Earth, on which latitude and longitude play the role of theta and phi.  These coordinates also feature some pathologies - for example, the poles on the Earth do not correspond to a unique value of the longitude.  Dealing with these so-called coordinate singularities has hampered the implementation of numerical relativity in spherical coordinates - at least in the absence of any symmetries - for a long time.  In recent years, however, collaborators of mine and I introduced new techniques that avoid these problems.  One advantage of this approach is that it allows us to resolve objects that are very different in size, for example black holes that are much smaller than other objects in the simulation.  Funding from this NSF grant has supported the implementation of these techniques in community codes, so that they can be used by other researchers as well.

 

One problem for which this approach has been very useful is the simulation of very small black holes that have been captured by a neutron star and then "swallow" the host star.  This scenario would be realized if tiny "primordial" black holes formed in the early Universe, contributed to the dark-matter content of the Universe, and ended up colliding with neutron stars.   If so, the observed existence of neutron star populations would place limits on the number and masses of such black holes.  Our numerical simulations of this process, together with analytical calculations, place firm limits on the time that it would take such black holes to swallow the entire star, which is a key ingredient in the above arguments.

 

I have also used the above approach to study so-called critical phenomena in gravitational collapse - phenomena that appear at the threshold of black-hole formation, and that reflect remarkable properties of Einstein?s theory.  Discovered originally in 1993 by Matt Choptuik, most studies of critical phenomena (with some notable exceptions) have been limited to spherical symmetry.  My new code in spherical coordinates is ideally suited to relax this assumption, and to study effects that appear only in the absence of spherical symmetry.  In addition to several calculations that study the effects of rotation and aspherical deformations, my collaborators and I studied critical phenomena in the collapse of electromagnetic waves.  While these electromagnetic wave are interesting in their own right, they also help us understand and anticipate some of the issues related to the "pure gravity" critical collapse - namely that of gravitational waves - which, to date, remains a largely unsolved problem.

 

Support from this grant has also allowed me to work with several Bowdoin undergraduate students, for whom involvement in a research project complements their in-class education.  These research projects result in interesting new results, several have been published in peer-reviewed journals with students as lead-authors, and several students have had the opportunity to present their research at conferences and workshops.
